common_questions: why not do this as a career?
leetcode - just want to get a better idea, is there a higher chance of getting asked leetcode, or more specific fundamental stuff?
the recruiter or checked out the JD in detail?
explain what happens when a host tries to send a udp packet to another host on the othe
explain your thought process clearly, and consider scalability and performance implicat
explain different technologies and concepts, with some relatively easy LC questions as
tell me about a time…” sessions so I didn’t ramble when asked about stakeholder conflict or c
how would you build X” scenarios
explaining complex technical concepts clearly since communication skills matter as much
describe Linux like the person in the video
explaining mutex vs spinlock at a high level
interview_tips: you draw from a wide variety of sources and hear others' testimonials when planning for interviews
reading *Clean Code* by Robert Cecil Martin
trying to get into some Open Source communities, contributing and developing as a hobby
EPI (elements of programming interviews) if you have the spare funds / time
you know first principles around mutexes/critical sections in general
from people who’ve been through similar high-pressure interviews, where the technical bar and expectations are high
anyone has on what I'll be asked? I have a lot of experience working in Cloud, so I feel very confident/excited for these topics
for prep in general? Do they ask Leetcode questions? Thank you for any suggestions!
red_flags: just come up with the algorithm
do too many problems without making sure you remember how to do ones you did a while back
truly understand the problems you've done and rather are simply memorizing the solutions
let a weak resume stop you from shooting your shot
got asked about these trivial roles
have my sights strictly on CS for a career but it is the only option I'm considering that I've thoroughly enjoyed
touch what an actual software job is like
know how many applications I have sent out, maybe 700+

process_insights.format: Mix of phone screen, technical, behavioral, on-site, virtual
